articles.title: Neural responses to reward may serve as a transdiagnositic brain-based marker of suicidal ideation - PsyPost
articles.description: New research published in Biological Psychology suggests that the way the brain responds to rewards and losses could be an important indicator of the risk of suicidal thoughts in individuals with depression and social anxiety. The study found that lower rewar…
articles.content: How the brain responds to rewards and losses may be a useful indicator of the risk of suicidal ideation among those suffering from depression and social anxiety, according to new research published i… [+7877 chars]

articles.title: BTN3A3 evasion promotes the zoonotic potential of influenza A viruses - Nature.com
articles.description: A protein that evolved in primates, BTN3A3, is expressed in human airways and shows antiviral activity against avian IAVs but not against human IAVs.

articles.author: Barbara Jacquelyn Sahakian, Marjan Biria, Trevor Robbins
articles.title: People with obsessive-compulsive disorder have an imbalance of brain chemicals – our discovery could mean a treatment breakthrough - The Conversation
articles.description: Completely new forms of drugs may soon be available to treat obsessive-compulsive disorder.
articles.content: People often jokingly say theyve got a bit of OCD (obsessive-compulsive disorder) if they are overly organised or tidy. But OCD is actually a severe and disabling disorder characterised by obsessions… [+5454 chars]

articles.title: Around 20 per cent of people who had COVID could experience long-term symptoms - Sky News Australia
articles.description: Southern Cross University Professor Jon Wardle says about 20 per cent of people who end up with COVID will experience Long COVID symptoms, and how long those symptoms will last are unknown.
articles.content: Southern Cross University Professor Jon Wardle says about 20 per cent of people who end up with COVID will experience Long COVID symptoms, and how long those symptoms will last are unknown.
